name: The Maheo'o
description: The sacred powers of the Tsitsistas — the Cheyenne people — who migrated from the western Great Lakes onto the northern Plains and built one of the most coherent religious-political systems in indigenous North America. What makes the Cheyenne system remarkable, and what Grinnell documented in The Cheyenne Indians as early as 1923, is that the sacred and the civic are not parallel tracks but the same track. Sweet Medicine received the Sacred Arrows and the laws of governance simultaneously at Bear Butte in the Black Hills. The Council of Forty-Four chiefs, the military societies, the Sun Dance, the Arrow Renewal — these are not separate institutions but a single integrated architecture. Karl Schlesier's The Wolves of Heaven reconstructed Cheyenne ceremonialism as a system of cosmic maintenance: the Sun Dance is not merely a petition to the sacred powers but an annual renewal of the world itself, a ritual in which the universe is taken apart and reassembled. The Cheyenne call their sacred beings Maheo'o, and the term encompasses not a ranked pantheon but a web of powers — creator, prophet, culture hero, directional spirit, water being — whose relationships constitute the order of the world.

deities.name: Ma'heo'o
deities.title: The All-Father / The Creator
deities.description: Ma'heo'o is the supreme creator, the sacred power who existed before the world and who brought everything into being through thought and will. In the Cheyenne creation account recorded by Grinnell and elaborated by Schlesier, Ma'heo'o floated on the primordial water and sent diving birds — first the snow goose, then the loon, then the mudhen, then the coot — down into the depths to bring up mud from which the earth could be formed. Only the coot succeeded, returning with a ball of mud that Ma'heo'o shaped and expanded into the land. He then created people, animals, plants, and the structures of ceremony that would sustain the world. But Ma'heo'o is not a micromanager. After creation, he does not intervene directly in the way that the Greek gods drop onto battlefields or Yahweh speaks from burning bushes. Instead, he operates through intermediaries — the culture heroes Sweet Medicine and Erect Horns, the Sacred Arrows and the Sacred Buffalo Hat, the spirits of the four directions. This is a theology of delegation, and it maps onto a political philosophy. The Council of Forty-Four chiefs governed the Cheyenne nation through consensus, not command; the supreme chief held moral authority but could not compel obedience. The political structure mirrors the theological one. Ma'heo'o created the order and entrusted its maintenance to those who live within it. The implication is that human beings are not subjects of the creator but stewards of creation — which is a burden, not a privilege. If the ceremonies lapse, if the arrows are not renewed, if the Sun Dance is not performed, the world itself degrades. Ma'heo'o made the world, but the Cheyenne hold it together.

deities.name: Heammawihio
deities.title: The Wise One Above
deities.description: Heammawihio is the Wise One Above — the sky-dwelling spiritual power sometimes identified with Ma'heo'o and sometimes distinguished as a separate aspect of the sacred. The ambiguity is instructive. Grinnell noted that Cheyenne informants used Heammawihio and Ma'heo'o in overlapping ways, and early missionaries seized on Heammawihio as a translation for the Christian God, which flattened a more interesting theological landscape. Heammawihio is specifically the power above, the sky presence, the being who watches from the direction the smoke rises toward. In the Sun Dance lodge, the center pole connects the earth to the sky, and the dancers' gazing upward is directed toward Heammawihio's domain. He is the recipient of the smoke offerings that rise from the Sacred Pipe, the presence addressed when the pipe stem is pointed upward in the four-direction prayer. John Stands In Timber, in Cheyenne Memories, described Heammawihio as the power to whom the Cheyenne pray in moments of extremity — in battle, in famine, in the Sun Dance ordeal. But the relationship is not supplication; it is communication between relatives. The Cheyenne did not grovel before the Wise One Above any more than they groveled before a respected elder. They spoke to him directly, explained their situation, made offerings, and trusted the relationship. Heammawihio's association with the above-direction places him in the architectural logic of the Sun Dance lodge, where the vertical axis — earth to sky, pole base to pole tip — represents the path between human need and sacred response.

deities.name: Ahktunowihio
deities.title: The One Who Lives Under the Ground
deities.description: Ahktunowihio is the power beneath the earth, the counterpart to Heammawihio above. Where Heammawihio receives smoke and prayer directed upward, Ahktunowihio holds the roots, the buried things, the dead, and the generative forces that push upward through the soil as grass and timber. Together, Heammawihio and Ahktunowihio define the vertical axis of the Cheyenne cosmos — the same axis that the Sun Dance center pole physically instantiates. Schlesier documented that Cheyenne ceremonialism presupposes a layered universe: the sky world above, the earth surface where humans live, and the underground world below, each populated by its own beings and governed by its own logic. Ahktunowihio is not a devil or an underworld lord in the European sense; the below-world is not a place of punishment but a place of power, transformation, and gestation. Seeds germinate there. The dead return there. The roots of the sacred cottonwood tree — chosen for the Sun Dance pole specifically because it is the tree that grows near water and whose roots reach deep — extend into Ahktunowihio's domain. In the Cheyenne creation account, the earth was formed from mud brought up from beneath the primordial water, which means the material of the world itself came from below. Ahktunowihio is the custodian of that original substance. The psychological parallel is the relationship between conscious life and the unconscious depths that sustain it — the recognition that what appears on the surface is fed by what is hidden, and that the hidden world has its own intelligence and its own demands.

deities.name: Nonoma
deities.title: Thunder / The Thunderbird
deities.description: Nonoma is the Thunder — the great storm power of the Plains, analogous to the Lakota Wakinyan but carrying Cheyenne-specific ceremonial weight. Thunder is not a deity who happens to control weather; thunder is a sacred being whose voice is the sound of the storm itself. On the Great Plains, where the horizon extends unbroken in every direction and storm systems are visible for a hundred miles, thunder is not background noise. It is an event. The Cheyenne understood thunder as a living presence that communicated through its own medium, and the lightning that accompanied it was the visible expression of that communication. Grinnell recorded that the Cheyenne treated the first thunder of spring as a significant ceremonial moment — the return of the Thunder marked the transition from winter's stillness to summer's vitality, the signal that the Sun Dance season was approaching. Nonoma is associated with the warrior societies and with the courage required to face overwhelming force. The Thunder does not negotiate; it arrives, and you either endure it or you don't. Cheyenne warriors who dreamed of thunder received specific ceremonial obligations and privileges, much as Lakota heyoka dreamers did. The storm is the test that cannot be prepared for — it arrives on its own schedule, with its own intensity, and the only possible response is presence. The military societies that organized Cheyenne warfare operated on a similar principle: when the battle arrived, you stood your ground. The Dog Soldiers, the most famous of the Cheyenne warrior societies, staked themselves to the ground with a sash and did not retreat. That is Nonoma's logic applied to human conduct.

deities.name: Sweet Medicine
deities.title: The Prophet / Bringer of the Sacred Arrows
deities.description: Sweet Medicine is the central prophetic figure of Cheyenne tradition — the culture hero who traveled to Bear Butte (Nowah'wus) in the Black Hills and received Mahuts, the four Sacred Arrows, from the Maheo'o spirits who dwelt inside the mountain. Two arrows held power over human beings, and two held power over the buffalo, and together they constituted the covenant between the Cheyenne people and the sacred powers that sustained their world. Peter Powell's Sweet Medicine is the definitive scholarly treatment, and it traces the arrow traditions with extraordinary care. But Sweet Medicine did not bring only the arrows. He brought the laws. He established the Council of Forty-Four — the governing body of peace chiefs who led the Cheyenne nation through consensus, moral authority, and personal sacrifice rather than coercion. The chiefs served ten-year terms, could not go to war during their tenure, and were expected to be the most generous people in the camp, giving away their own property before asking anything of others. Sweet Medicine brought religion and governance as a single package, and this is the point that matters psychologically: in the Cheyenne system, law is not imposed from outside by a sovereign; it emerges from the same sacred encounter that gives the people their relationship to the divine. The arrows and the council are one gift. John Stands In Timber recorded Sweet Medicine's prophecy with devastating specificity: he foretold the coming of a strange people with light skin, the arrival of cattle that would replace the buffalo, the appearance of a being that would make people crazy — widely interpreted as alcohol — and the eventual loss of the Cheyenne way of life. He told them this before he died, and he was right about all of it. Sweet Medicine is not a god but something arguably more psychologically complex: a human being who entered the sacred, received what the sacred offered, brought it back, built a civilization on it, and then warned that civilization of its own destruction.

deities.name: Erect Horns
deities.title: Bringer of the Sun Dance
deities.description: Erect Horns (Tomsi'vehe) is the culture hero who brought the Sun Dance — Oxheheom, the New Life Lodge — to the Cheyenne, just as Sweet Medicine brought the Sacred Arrows. If the Sacred Arrows are the covenant between the Cheyenne and the powers that govern their survival, the Sun Dance is the annual renewal of the cosmos itself. Schlesier's The Wolves of Heaven reconstructs the Sun Dance as a world-renewal ceremony of staggering ambition: over the course of the ritual, the universe is symbolically disassembled and reassembled. The sacred lodge is the world in miniature — its center pole is the axis mundi, its walls are the horizon, its interior is the whole of creation. The pledger who vows to perform the Sun Dance carries the obligation on behalf of the entire people, and the ceremony requires the participation of the community: gathering the materials, selecting the cottonwood tree, raising the lodge, preparing the sacred objects. Erect Horns received the Sun Dance from Maheo'o inside a sacred mountain — the parallel with Sweet Medicine's experience at Bear Butte is structural and deliberate. Both culture heroes entered a mountain, encountered the sacred powers, received a central institution, and brought it back to the people. One brought governance and the arrows; the other brought the ceremony that renews the world. Together, they constitute the two pillars of Cheyenne civilization: the political and the cosmological. Erect Horns also brought the Sacred Buffalo Hat (Esevone/Is'siwun), a buffalo-skin cap with two horns that holds power over the buffalo herds and thus over the subsistence of the people. The Buffalo Hat and the Sacred Arrows are the two most holy objects in the Cheyenne world, and they were traditionally kept by separate bands, a structural division that distributed sacred responsibility across the nation.

deities.name: Tomse'e
deities.title: The Sacred Spring Spirit
deities.description: Tomse'e — sometimes rendered as Tomtse or identified with specific spring or water ceremonialism — represents the spirit associated with sacred springs, the renewal of water, and the underground sources that sustain life on the semiarid Plains. Water on the Great Plains is not guaranteed. The Cheyenne lived in a landscape where rivers could run dry, where springs were lifelines, where knowing the location of water sources was survival knowledge of the highest order. Tomse'e embodies the sacredness of these sources — the recognition that water emerging from underground is not merely a hydrological event but a gift from the powers beneath the earth. Grinnell documented that the Cheyenne held specific springs and water sources as sacred sites, places where the boundary between the surface world and the underground world was thin, where offerings were made and ceremonies performed. The spring is a liminal place: water that was hidden becomes visible, what was below comes above, what was contained is released. In the framework of Cheyenne cosmology, where Ahktunowihio governs the below-world and Heammawihio governs the above, the spring is the point of communication between them — the place where the underground world sends its gifts to the surface. Tomse'e's ceremonial significance reflects a broader Plains understanding that water is not a commodity but a relative, and that the places where water appears are sacred thresholds. This is not metaphor. On the northern Plains, a reliable spring could sustain a winter camp, and its failure could mean death. The sacred and the practical were, as always in Cheyenne thought, the same thing.

deities.name: Yellow Haired Woman
deities.title: Keeper of Sacred Knowledge
deities.description: Yellow Haired Woman is a figure who appears in Cheyenne sacred narrative as a carrier of ceremonial knowledge, particularly associated with the massaum (the animal dance or Contrary Ceremony) and with the sacred traditions that women transmitted within Cheyenne society. Her significance lies partly in what she reveals about the structure of Cheyenne religious authority: it was not exclusively male. While Sweet Medicine and Erect Horns are the most prominent culture heroes, the Cheyenne system included women as essential ceremonial actors. The Sacred Buffalo Hat was traditionally attended by a woman keeper. Women's quillwork societies held sacred knowledge with the same gravity as men's military societies. The massaum ceremony, which Schlesier analyzed as one of the oldest strata of Cheyenne ceremonialism — potentially predating the migration onto the Plains — involved the ritual enactment of the relationship between humans and animals, and Yellow Haired Woman's role in this tradition connects her to the deep-time layer of Cheyenne spirituality that preceded the horse-and-buffalo culture most outsiders associate with the Plains. She represents the stratum of knowledge that survived the ecological and cultural transformations of the Cheyenne migration from the Great Lakes, through the Missouri River farming villages, and onto the open grasslands. Every tradition has figures who carry the old knowledge through periods of radical change, and Yellow Haired Woman is one of those carriers. Her presence in the sacred narratives is a reminder that the Cheyenne ceremonial system was not invented on the Plains but was adapted from older sources, carried by people who remembered what mattered and translated it into new conditions.

deities.name: The Four Sacred Direction Spirits
deities.title: Guardians of the Cardinal Directions
deities.description: The Four Sacred Direction Spirits stand at the cardinal points of the Cheyenne cosmos and govern the qualities associated with each direction. They are addressed in every pipe ceremony, every Sun Dance, every Arrow Renewal — the pipe stem is pointed to each of the four directions in sequence, acknowledging the spirits who hold the world in place. The directions are not merely spatial; they are qualitative. Each carries its own color, its own season, its own teachings, and its own challenges. The exact correspondences vary among Cheyenne sources — Grinnell, Stands In Timber, and Schlesier record slightly different color assignments, which reflects the fact that oral tradition is living tradition, not a fixed text — but the structural logic is consistent: the four directions define the horizontal plane of the world, just as Heammawihio and Ahktunowihio define the vertical axis. Together, they create the six-directional framework — north, south, east, west, above, below — that organizes Cheyenne ceremonial space. The Sun Dance lodge is oriented to these directions; the opening faces east, toward the rising sun. The Council of Forty-Four chiefs sat in a specific arrangement within the council lodge that mapped onto the directional system. The Cheyenne camp circle, when the bands gathered for summer ceremonies, was organized directionally, each band occupying its traditional position. This is what it means to say that religion and governance were the same system: the political geography of the camp replicated the sacred geography of the cosmos. Every meeting, every ceremony, every camp was a map of the world.

deities.name: Vo'estanehesono
deities.title: Spirit of the Whirlwind
deities.description: Vo'estanehesono, the Whirlwind Spirit, represents the chaotic, spinning, untamable force of wind on the open Plains — not the steady directional winds governed by the Four Direction Spirits but the sudden, violent, rotational force that appears without warning and destroys without pattern. Tornadoes on the Great Plains are among the most visually dramatic natural phenomena on Earth: visible from miles away as dark funnels descending from green-black supercell thunderheads, touching down on flat grassland where there is no shelter, carving paths of absolute destruction through a landscape that moments before was calm. The Cheyenne understood the whirlwind as a distinct spiritual power — not merely weather but a being with its own nature and its own logic, or rather its own refusal of logic. The whirlwind does not respect the orderly directional framework of the four sacred directions; it spins, combines all directions into one, obliterates the distinction between north and south and east and west. It is the force that reminds you that the ordered cosmos, however beautiful its architecture, exists within a larger reality that includes chaos. Vo'estanehesono was treated with respect and caution in Cheyenne tradition — you did not speak casually about the whirlwind, you did not point at a tornado, you did not invite its attention. This is not superstition; it is the behavioral expression of a theological insight: some powers cannot be integrated into your system, only acknowledged. The whirlwind is the limit case of the Cheyenne cosmological order — the force that the six-directional framework cannot contain, the reminder that the map is not the territory.

deities.name: The Water Spirits
deities.title: Beings of Rivers, Lakes, and Springs
deities.description: The Water Spirits — inhabiting rivers, lakes, springs, and the underground waters that feed them — constitute a category of beings in Cheyenne thought that parallels the Lakota Unktehi and appears across Plains traditions under various names. They are not a single entity but a class of powerful, often dangerous beings who dwell in the places where water gathers and deepens. Grinnell recorded Cheyenne accounts of water beings who inhabited specific lakes and rivers, beings who could drag swimmers under, who controlled the movements of fish and waterfowl, and who demanded offerings from those who wished to use the water safely. These are not fairy tales told to keep children away from riverbanks, though they served that function too. They encode a relationship to water that treats it as inhabited territory — not empty resource but someone else's home. The ecological implications are significant: if the river is someone's dwelling, you do not foul it; if the spring is a sacred threshold, you do not divert it casually. The Water Spirits are connected to Ahktunowihio, the power beneath the earth, because groundwater is the below-world's gift to the surface. The springs sacred to the Cheyenne were understood as places where the Water Spirits permitted the underground world's wealth to flow upward. In the Sun Dance, water plays a specific ritual role — the dancers fast from water for the duration of the ceremony, and the first drink after the ordeal is a moment of profound renewal. The absence of water intensifies the dancer's awareness of what water means, and the return of water is the return of life itself. The Water Spirits hold that power: they are the custodians of the substance without which nothing survives.
